text.value:
The fact that there are integers that are not natural numbers suggests that the set of integers, , is in some sense bigger than the set of natural numbers, . In fact, we'll show they are the same size!

In order to do this, we need to have a rigorous way of comparing the size of sets, even when they are infinite. This requires the language of functions, with which you should be familiar.

Recall that a function is a mapping that is either many-one or one-one. We can illustrate functions between finite sets with mapping diagrams like the one below. This illustrates a function that maps elements from the set A = {a,b,c,d} to the set B = {1,2,3,4}. For example, we write (a) = 1 to indicate a gets mapped to 1 and draw a line from a to 1 to illustrate this.

Mapping diagrams for four functions are shown below. Categorise each of the following as either a many-one function, one-one function or not a function

value.value: each input gets mapped to a distinct output
each input gets mapped to a distinct output
A function can't have one input mapped to two separate outputs.
a and b get mapped to the same value.
